Class Reverse_Linked_List_II

java.lang.Object
Reverse_Linked_List_II
public class Reverse_Linked_List_II extends Object
LeetCode 92: Reverse Linked List II

Problem Description:
Given the head of a singly linked list and two integers left and right where left <= right, reverse the nodes of the list from position left to position right, and return the reversed list.

Sample Input / Output: 


 Example 1:
 Input:  head = [1,2,3,4,5], left = 2, right = 4
 Output: [1,4,3,2,5]

 Example 2:
 Input:  head = [5], left = 1, right = 1
 Output: [5]

Constraints:

  • The number of nodes in the list is n.
  • 1 invalid input: '<'= n invalid input: '<'= 500
  • -500 invalid input: '<'= Node.val invalid input: '<'= 500
  • 1 invalid input: '<'= left invalid input: '<'= right invalid input: '<'= n

  • Method Details

    • reverseBetweenArrayList

      public ListNode reverseBetweenArrayList(ListNode head, int left, int right)
      Reverses the sublist between left and right using an ArrayList to store references.

      Approach 1: ArrayList-Based (Simple but Less Efficient)

      Detailed Steps:

      1. Store all nodes in a list:
        • Create List<ListNode> and traverse the linked list.
        • Add each node to the ArrayList (preserving order).
      2. Reverse values between left and right:
        • Indices are left-1 to right-1 (0-based).
        • Use two-pointer technique on the ArrayList → swap values in place.
      3. Reconstruct list:
        • Since only values are swapped, no structural re-linking needed.
        • Return original head.

      Complexity:

      • Time: O(n) — traversal + reversal inside ArrayList.
      • Space: O(n) — stores all nodes in ArrayList.

    • reverseBetweenEfficient

      public ListNode reverseBetweenEfficient(ListNode head, int left, int right)
      Efficient in-place reversal of a sublist between left and right.

      Approach 2: In-Place Reversal (Efficient)

      Detailed Steps:

      1. Initialize dummy node:
        • Create dummy = new ListNode(0, head).
        • Use pointer prev to reach the node before left.
      2. Identify sublist:
        • curr = prev.next → first node in sublist.
      3. Reverse sublist by shifting nodes:
        • Repeat right - left times:
        • Take out node after curr → next = curr.next.
        • Detach next and insert it right after prev.
        • Reconnect pointers accordingly.
      4. Reconnect list:
        • Dummy ensures even if left=1, logic works seamlessly.

      Complexity:

      • Time: O(n) — single traversal, localized reversal.
      • Space: O(1) — in-place operations only.
